p.s: To present the reader his view about the development of learning foreign languages in the UK the author John Worne useuses a clear structure, persuasive techniques and stylistic devices in his article.
John Worne's article Language learning in the UK: can't, won't, don't is from a popular paper.
This is a parent throughtthrough the mix of facts and own opinion aspects in the article (cf. l. 16, 9-10).
Furthermore the syntax is not that difficult and Worne uses colloquial language.
In some sentences he also useuses an emotional style of writing (cf. l. 4).
In the article aren't any quotes from expert's or something like that.
The article is adressedaddressed to general audience so there isn't any knowledge which must know the reader.
In the first paragraphs John Worne introduces the topic and listlists some facts which describe the situation.
After that he criticisecriticises all the people who don't fight enough for a development of language learning in the UK.
Because his opinion is that people in the UK I haven't the necessary language skills to keep up with other countries in the world.
He thinks that this skills should be improved.
Then John Worne underlines his opinion with the argument that language learning is vital for the UK's future prosperity and global standing and essential for trade, diplomacy, etc. (cf. l. 16-18).
Another argument which John Worne brings in to state his opinion is that two-thirds of UK-businesses need foreign languages.
He proveproves this argument with a survey from CBI/Pearson for Education and Skills.
Another argument which states his opinion is that the combination of specialist and linguist knowledge is very attractive for employers.
To describe that John Worne uses an example in line 28-29: [...] a lawyer with Chinese language skills is more in demand than a pure lawyer or a pure linguist.
In the last paragraphs hesays how important it is that people in the UK, mostly young people, have to improve their language skills (cf. l. 30-31) and what the other people can do.
He remindreminds the parents about their duty to see that their kids learn foreign languages.
John Worne uses in some lines irony to criticise the opinion and the thinking of some people (cf. l. 6-7, l. 12-15).
He also uses aan anaphora in line 16-17 which underlines how important language learning and foreign languages are.
he also often uses brackets which has the effect that the symptoms gets more attention by the reader than other.
All in all one can say that the author is really worried about the foreign linguistic development of the UK.
He thinks that young people have to improve their language skills so that the UK keepkeeps up there future prosperity and global standing.
John Worne sees the language learning as a vital and essential for the trade, cultural exports, national security and diplomacy.

His opinion he underlines with a clear structure in his article, many arguments which sometimes are support by examples and some stylistic devices mostly the use of irony, anaphoras and the use of brackets.
